history.content: For me personally, 186 was quite helpful in industry, not specifically with databases but just dealing with extensive projects in Java.

children.subject: Not very useful for industry. But definitely some interesting projects and it was very interesting for me.

Agreed. The content is not very useful for industry, but you get great experience working with a large code base. So don't take the course thinking it will give you direct knowledge that is applicable to everyday work(depending on your job, it might actually), but take it if you want to have experience looking into multiple files to find functions and variables that will help you implement your current function. That's a big part of working as a Software Engineer, and if you don't take 186, it's fine. It doesn't take much time during an internship or full work to get experience doing this.

186 was the most useful class I've taken for industry. I have done two internships and while I didn't work in databases, the project is the most practical and comprehensive I've taken similar to working in large codebases. It is super useful to have practice navigating and building good abstractions and organized code, which 186 really helps with. 162 is very good as well for this purpose (navigating large codebases and debugging), but 186 had nicer real software tools like Java/Intellij, Unit Testing, Docker, etc.

I highly recommend this class!

history.content:
Just curious about how useful 186 is for industry / in general. I've heard mixed reviews. Especially for people who have had some sort of backend industry experience - did you see 186 as being helpful or necessary?

(also was it an enjoyable class?)

I'm running out of time to take things so I'm not sure if it's worth to take 186 or take something that seems more interesting to me but that I may not use (like 270 or 182). As far as systems classes I know I'll take 162, 161, 168.

Thanks for any input!
history.subject: 186 Useful for Industry?
